STRINGS: That night--
"Soujirou Sekimoto, stand up and place your hands on the back wall!!"
Following the officer's commands without any complaints,
he put his hands on the furthest wall and turned his back to us.
"Inmate, compliance confirmed!"
"Compliance confirmed!! Unlocking!!"
"Unlocking confirmed!"
"Unlocking confirmed! Open the door!!"
The duo of officers conducted themselves
perfectly according to protocol.
Chief Kuroda and I watched over them in silence.
And speaking of Chief Kuroda,
I could faintly see an internal conflict in his expression.
"Handcuff inmate Soujirou Sekimoto!!"
"Handcuffs!!"
"Handcuffs confirmed!!"
"Handcuffs confirmed!"
Once they made sure Sekimoto was securely shackled,
they spun him forward and pushed him along to us.
"Good work.
As of present time, custody of Soujirou Sekimoto
has been transferred to S Prefectural Police, C Town Substation,
Specialized Patrol Division Chief Kunio Kuroda."
We offered them a salute as they handed him over to us.
Then I held Sekimoto's waistband with a steely grip.
Even after exiting the jail cells,
officers posted at regular intervals monitored Sekimoto.
They were engaging in tight surveillance in case of an emergency.
After all, bringing a murderer still on trial along
as an observer is an unprecedented occurrence.
"Let's go."
I quietly-- audibly enough for just his ears to hear--
urged him to move.
Going up to the ground floor,
the white glow of flourescent lights dazzled our surroundings.
The station's ground floor had an utterly different air to it as well.
The common citizens who we'd usually catch sporadic glimpses of
were nowhere in sight.
They probably were cleared out for Sekimoto's convoy.
Even the TVs used to kill time while waiting for our turns
were turned off. In their place, the officials watched
our escort progress, still positioned in regular intervals.
We stood as the center of their focus.
I was reminded of something that resembled this situation.
It was--
"...the Pied Piper of Hamelin."
I mumbled to myself in a low voice without thinking,
which was brought to my attention by Chief Kuroda clearing his throat.
This really is like the Pied Piper of Hamelin.
When all is said and done, we are the magus.
Sekimoto is the mouses he led out of town.
And the ones observing us are the populace of Hamelin.
To the others, Sekimoto most likely is no different from
a mouse that invaded their house.
After having the pace of their investigation disturbed,
they surely must be feeling relieved.
But was Sekimoto really at fault?
Even if they drive him out of this town,
the real calamity-- Blindman won't just be forced out in the open.
In the substation's lobby entrance, the chief of police expected us.
Chief Kuroda and I saluted him.
"Chief. We, Kunio Kuroda and Saki Houjou, both members of the
Specialized Patrol Division, shall begin the escort of consultant
Soujirou Sekimoto to the Tokyo Detention House as of now."
"I hope you are fully aware of the importance of your duty,
and for a safe and secure execution thereof.
I wish you the best."
"Yessir!"
We performed a salute to the Chief of Police once again.
And in front of the entrance, a one-box minivan waited for us
with its engine already turned on.
The minivan had its rear windows tinted white,
making checking the inside impossible.
I opened the rear door.
There a plain car seat awaited us.
"Consultant, boarding."
"Boarding!!"
"...Please get in."
I nudged Sekimoto to get aboard the car.
Then I got in myself and closed the door the same instant.
This car outwardly looks like a regular automobile,
but in fact, it's a special vehicle modified for police use.
Once someone boards the back seats,
they can't go outside without authorization from the driver's seat.
Chief Kuroda mounted the passenger seat.
Initially, we were going to seat Sekimoto between us,
but since we are after all using the pretext of escorting a consultant,
and this car model is a three-door type, I alone accompanied him.
"Are you guys in the back ready?"
"Yes, please begin."
Chief Kuroda checked up on us through the wire mesh
that divided the front and back seats.
Having receiving my reply,
he requested the driver in the driver's seat to start driving.
Driving originally was Mr. Kazamori's role.
But now that he's not here, the NPA prepared one for us.
"Well then, let's go."
At Chief Kuroda's short declaration,
the car quietly departed.
Leaving the station behind, we cut through the town center,
and swiftly reached a narrow mountain road.
The bleak path continued for some time.
Neither Sekimoto nor I could see what was going on outside
from the back seats. We simply shook from side to side.
I silently stared forward.
Occasionally, I'd pay attention to Sekimoto, but he too
silently faced forward, his posture perfectly straight.
The scenery seen from the windscreen was mere darkness.
The headlights barely illuminated what was just ahead,
and I wouldn't decribe the visibility as very good.
As though foretelling our future,
it seemed to stoke the anxiety within us.
This landscape will persist for a while longer.
After arriving at the built-up mountain base,
it'll take one hour in the expressway to reach Tokyo.
In other words, I will never see Sekimoto again in a little bit.
When I realized that, I turned to check on Sekimoto yet another time.
"Would you be so kind as to grant me permission
to talk despite the present situation?"
He addressed me in a quiet tone
so the two in the front seats wouldn't notice.
"When you came to C Town, we both were chatting away.
But I don't know if we had permission to do that ourselves."
"We're the Special Division,
a window-sitting department without actual windows.
We're seldom participants in these kinds of convoys."
"I see. By all rights, being obedient now would be for the best.
But, I imagine this will be my last chance to speak with you."
"I had the same feeling.
That said, I don't really have anything to discuss, though."
"But, well... thank you."
I made a tiny bow.
Catching sight of it, he chuckled.
"Again you express appreciation to a murderer.
Had one of the people in front saw it, you'd be in trouble."
"...I don't care anymore."
Then, silence.
For a transient moment, a wordless void prevailed.
"The reason why I cooperated with you--
I said it was because I wanted to see Blindman's true identity
with my own eyes. However, that wasn't the truth."
The words that abruptly broke the ice
made me turn to his direction without thinking.
"What... do you mean by that?"
"Of course, wanting to learn what lot utilized Blindman
in their schemes was part of it.
After all, proding into their psychology could further my research."
"But I had other intentions as well.
That is not to say that I hoped to let that monster loose, though."
"I just wanted to let the fear of Blindman sprout
on the public's hearts.
Not once did I desire these killings to occur."
"But the fact is that it was born in the real world, a monster
bearing the name of Blindman, endlessly perpetrating violence.
My heart is troubled by that."
"I expected you to be a much colder person than that."
"People tease me, calling me a mad scientist or cold-blooded.
But even I am human. I have a human heart."
"I feel responsible.
I wanted to take responsibility for the monster
I unintentionally created. That's why I spoke up at my trial."
"After all, that is the time when they'd pay the most attention
to what I'd have to say. And if the media picked up on it,
they would've had no way of ignoring me."
"You mentioned that before as well.
Taking responsibility...
But how are you going to do that exactly?"
"As the creator of a monster, I should teach it the correct path.
Otherwise, teaching it how to wield power as a monster
wouldn't be a bad idea itself."
I stared at Sekimoto without thinking.
He looked forward with not even a passing glance towards me.
"Teaching it how to wield power as a monster...
What is that... supposed to mean?"
"Everything born into this world has a purpose.
Thus, I shall bestow Blindman one as well.
I, its creator."
"Is that to commit more massacres?"
Sekimoto sighed.
"...What have you learned over the course of our conversations?"
"I am no more than a folklorist, a researcher of urban legends.
Not a specialist in killing."
"When it comes to that, Blindman is much better than I.
All I can do is give a motive to that beast."
"Isn't that the same thing, though?
You're trying to use these cases to keep Blindman alive
in people's minds through urban legends."
"You want to satisfy your craving for the limelight
by breathing life into Blindman,
what was supposed to be a fictional being, aren't you?"
Sekimoto stared at me without a word.
I threw a sharp glare at him in wait for his reply.
I might have misunderstood Soujirou Sekimoto as a person.
As the case developed, he would supply us with various hints
from an unbelievable perspective.
When put into practice, they helped us get tangible results.
Something similar happened at the time of Mr. Kazamori's death.
He whipped me back into shape with a harsh but fair pep talk.
I gradually reevaluated my conception of him
through these events.
But his true colors were always those of a mere eccentric.
Is he just someone unworthy of being trusted?
"Answer me.
Do you hope to bring about even more slaughter by way of Blindman?
Was that your real intentions?"
"...I don't know, I wonder.
Figure it out yourself."
"Woah, look out!!"
Upon pulling the emergency brake of the minivan,
our bodies floated in the air for but a moment.
"What happened?"
"What... is that...?"
Chief Kuroda pointed ahead.
Something was just in front of us.
"A... person?"
Although I called it a person,
I wasn't confident in that yet.
The reason why was the much too peculiar attire it wore.
The 'thing' before us had its whole body draped
in raggedy fabric.
"A fox or tanuki has to be playing tricks on us,
there's no way somebody would be strolling in a place like this."
Certainly, this is a mountain road, not a popular boulevard.
It's unthinkable that someone would be here at this time of night.
"This has to be some wildlife that picked up a rag somewhere
and accidentally got it stuck on their head.
Hey, driver, could you press the horn?"
The 'thing' in front of us reacted to the horn,
sluggishly moving.
It shifted over there.
It shifted over here.
As if it didn't know where it was.
"What the, that's way too creepy."
"We can't afford to waste time here.
I'm going to go take a look, wait here."
Chief Kuroda opened the passenger seat's door and went outside.
Then he slowly approached that 'thing'.
"Just what is that... I wonder."
At that time, for reasons unknown,
Soujirou Sekimoto raised a corner of his mouth to form a smile.
--Why is he grinning at a time like this?
"UWAAAAHH!"
Suddenly, Chief Kuroda screamed at the top of his lungs.
I turned away as if to repel that cry,
just as Chief Kuroda's legs failed him.
"Houjou, Houjou!!
Contact the station! Call for backup!!"
"Chief Kuroda!? What happened!?"
"It's him! He's here!!"
"Sorry, but let me out!
You stay here!"
I ran up to Chief Kuroda's side.
He was still quivering in shock.
"Chief Kuroda!"
"T-t-th-th-thi-this is...!?"
Following his pointing finger,
I saw that it was the rag-wrapped 'thing'.
Having noticed our presence,
it didn't stop shifting yet.
Its actions were quite sluggish.
We could hear it dragging its feet, so maybe it couldn't move well.
At the same time, a faint stench tickled my nostrils.
It made me recall a metallic, oily sensation all over my tongue.
Could it be... blood?
I checked near that 'thing's' feet.
Under the cover of darkness I couldn't be certain,
but I did at least make out a dark fluid trickling onto the ground.
"...Are you injured?"
"Ah...aaah...ah..."
Howling came from under that cloth.
Upon hearing its voice, I instinctively knew.
"No way... a person?
Wait, hey, are you okay!?!"
It was the instant I tried approaching,
the fabric that covered them from head to toe slipped off.
"You're kidding me...!?
You're... Haruka Minase!?"
"Uhn...uugghhh...ooh...!"
The area around both of her eyes was a deep crimson.
Tormented and in pain,
she could only wriggle and twitch like a baby.
It was evident that Blindman had gotten their hands on her.
"Who the hell did this to you!?!"
"Oooohh...uuuuhhhnnn...!"
"Blindman did this to you, didn't it!?
Where did that bastard go!?"
She showed no response to my questions at all.
No, she couldn't respond.
At times, she would open and close her mouth,
letting me peer into her oral cavity,
and also see that her tongue had been completely cut off.
Her capability of speech had been sealed away.
Ms. Haruka's bleeding showed no signs of stopping yet.
Meaning that not much time had passed
since receiving those injuries.
Taking one more complete look at her physical condition,
I determined what had to be done before everything else.
It was to--
